messages.content: Why do I need to use "git branch -M main" when pushing an existing repository?

The command `git branch -M main` is used to rename the current branch to "main" and change its name to the default branch name. This command is typically used when you are pushing an existing repository to a new repository, as the default branch name in the new repository is typically set to "main". However, it can also be used when you want to change the name of the current branch for any reason.
And what about "git push -u origin main"?

The command `git push -u origin main` is used to push the current branch to the remote repository, and set the remote branch to the default branch name. The `-u` flag stands for "update" and is used to update the remote branch with the local branch, and the `origin` is the name of the remote repository. The `main` flag is used to set the remote branch to the default branch name. This command is typically used when you are pushing an existing repository to a new repository, as the default branch name in the new repository is typically set to "main".
It's important to note that this command will overwrite the remote branch with the current local one and it will cause any local changes in the branch to be lost.
What would be the next step when pushing a local repo to GitHub?

The next step after running the `git push -u origin main` command is to confirm that the push was successful. You can do this by checking the output of the command, which will indicate whether the push was successful or if there were any errors. If the push was successful, you should see a message similar to "Everything up-to-date" or "Successfully pushed." If there were any errors, you will see an error message explaining what went wrong.

If the push was successful, you can also check the remote repository on GitHub to confirm that the changes have been pushed. You can do this by navigating to the repository on the GitHub website and checking the branch history.

It's also a good practice to add the remote repository as a source in your local repository, in order to be able to push and pull changes from it.

`git remote add origin https://github.com/yourusername/yourrepo.git`

This command will add the remote repository to your local repository, so you can push and pull changes from it in the future.
